findings.title: DoS attack if orphan JoinSplit transactions are enabled
findings.description: Initial expensive verifications in transaction checking allow a DoS attack if orphan transactions with JoinSplits are enabled.

findings.title: Inheriting FindAndDelete from Bitcoin is considered dangerous
findings.description: Inheriting FindAndDelete from Bitcoin is considered a security risk.

findings.title: scriptSig malleability allows 51% attack by invalidating honest miners blocks
findings.description: The new CTransaction::GetTxid method does not include scriptSig fields in the hash calculation, allowing attackers to invalidate blocks by modifying the scriptSig fields of its transactions.

findings.title: Unlimited number of transaction proofs allows CPU-exhaustion attacks
findings.description: Zcash transactions can hold an unlimited number of JoinSplit proofs, allowing a CPU-exhaustion attack by verifying a heavy transaction that holds many vjoinsplit elements.

findings.title: Erroneous nValueOut range check allows CPU-exhaustion attacks
findings.description: Erroneous nValueOut range check allows CPU-exhaustion attacks

findings.title: Forever growing nullifier set will end up being stored in nonvolatile memory
findings.description: Each Zcash transaction that contains a JoinSplit proof adds two nullifier items to the nullifiers pool. Every nullifier must be kept forever to prevent double-spends. If the nullifier list becomes too large, transaction processing will be slowed down by external storage access.

findings.title: Forever growing commitment tree slows down commitment lookup
findings.description: The forever growing commitment tree can cause a slowdown in commitment lookup.

findings.title: Improper destination path validation in RPC calls allows arbitrary command execution
findings.description: Authenticated RPC users can create or overwrite existing files in any location of the system accessible by the zcashd daemon, allowing an attacker to overwrite or create critical files and achieve arbitrary command execution.

findings.title: Improper destination file permissions check in RPC calls could expose secret keys
findings.description: Authenticated RPC users can use certain methods to make copies of wallet data including secret keys. The permissions of pre-existing destination files are not checked by zcashd before overwriting them, potentially exposing secrets key to other users of the system.

findings.title: Information exposure through log files
findings.description: Private addresses and Information of protected transactions including plaintext of memo fields are logged to ~/.zcash/*/debug.log, a log file in persistent storage that is not necessarily encrypted.
